description.narrative: According to an Integrated Food Security Phase Classification Report (September, 2019) an estimated 6.35 million people (54% of the population) in South Sudan are Crisis affected (IPC Phase 3) or suffer worse acute food insecurity; an estimated 1.7 million people are faced with acute food insecurity or Emergency (IPC Phase 4); and 10,000 people are in Catastrophe (IPC phase 5). Compared to the same period in 2018, there is a slight reduction in the proportion of people facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse acute food insecurity by an estimated 5%. However, high levels of acute food insecurity still persist in the country. In both periods, these estimates are in the presence of humanitarian food assistance (IPC Report, 2019). Adolescence is already a turbulent time of change in a young person’s life that leads to instability, emergencies often vastly change or accelerate this transition to adulthood. Many adolescent girls and boys are pulled out of school to take on caretaker or breadwinner roles at home, or become separated from their families. In Malakal, as in other conflict-affect areas of South Sudan, adolescent girls are disproportionally affected by the crisis, as they face gender discrimination in accessing food, education and health care, and experience several levels of gender-based violence. Failing to provide tailored and comprehensive responses to the unique needs and risks of adolescents, has devastating and long-term consequences. In 2020 we will remain committed to driving changes in the Malakal to protect vulnerable adolescents in crisis settings. Adolescents between 10 and 19 years old are chronically overlooked in responses to humanitarian crises. Adolescent girls are especially left behind; they face extreme barriers to accessing essential services such as food, education and healthcare as girls are often not in decision-making position (including access to finances) within their household or due to the lack of available and accessible services. Girls and young women continue to drop out of school to be married too early which increases their lifelong health and wellbeing outcomes and increases their risks of gender-based violence including sexual violence. Missing out on an education increases a girls’ chance to have a low skilled and low paid job such as a street vendor which in turn, increases her chances to GBV.

Plan targets 12.831 individuals with Protection, multi-purpose cash and/or protection services in Malakal town and PoC. Specific target groups of this intervention include: vulnerable HHs headed by disabled men and women, vulnerable HHs headed by elderly people, vulnerable HHs headed by pregnant and lactating women, Vulnerable female headed HH, vulnerable HHs headed by chronically ill persons, vulnerable HHs in need of economical support hosting orphaned children, vulnerable HH with access to land for cultivation and one household member at least able to farm, looted HH that have still remained vulnerable, Child headed HHs, vulnerable Adolescent girls, including young caregivers, children and parents experiencing psychological distress and vulnerable HHs caring for children with labor and skill capacity.

SUMMARY: South Sudan remains in the grip of a serious humanitarian crisis throughout 2019, with the effects of years of conflict, displacement and lack of basic services continued to be felt throughout the country. Following a reassessment of humanitarian need at the end of the dry season in 2019, the overall number of people in need increased to 7.2 million, leaving 63% of the total population of South Sudan in need. Plan continues in 2020 to provide 12.831 vulnerable people in Malakal with integrated Food Security and emergency livelihood support as well as protection for children and survivors of gender based violence.
The SSJR6 is a continuation of the South Sudan program funded by the Dutch Relief Alliance.

title.narrative: Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: Number of people benefitting unconditional and unrestricted cash

comment.narrative: Number of people benefitting unconditional and unrestricted cash
women

A total of 4 rounds of unconditional cash transfer for 4 months had been given to 150 households (M=54 and F=96) reaching 984 individuals. 75 households (Male, 25 Female, 50) in Malakal town and 75 households (Male, 29 Female, 46) in PoC who were benefited for unconditional cash transfer. Our major challenges this year were the exchange rate and high price of commodities in the market that affects the beneficiares.
men

title.narrative: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, montoring and/or evaluation of the programme

comment.narrative: Number of crisis-affected people who are also involved in the design, implementation, montoring and/or evaluation of the programme
female

2 Project Management Committees were established, and Cash supervisory committees to oversee the project activities as well as to facilitate the project activities were formed. In POC, the committee is comprised of 12 individuals (M=2, F=10), while in Malakal town, the committee is also comprise of 12 individuals (M=2, F=10). Joint Inception meetings in PoC and Malakal town with the Ministry of Agriculture and other stakeholders, Office of Relief and Rehabilitation Commission (RRC) in Malakal town, along with the chiefs from different payams in Malakal town and sector leaders in PoC. 56 (M=19, F=37) individuals attended the inception meeting in Malakal town and the POC. About 40 stakeholders (Male 28 and Female 12) participated in the review meeting to access satisfaction on the project and they recommend continued collaboration between JR Project Management Committees and Protection of Civilian Camp Coordination and Camp management (PCCC), to ensure effective coordination at the community level which was in cooperated in SSJR 2021 design.

title.narrative: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets

comment.narrative: Number of people provided with resources to protect and start rebuilding livelihood assets
women

A total of 500 HHs (3,560 individuals) were identified, registered and verified for agricultural inputs: 350 households in Malakal town, (Female, 292 Male, 58) and 150 households in the Protection of Civilians (POC) site, (Male, 85 Female, 65) received agricultural inputs. In order to improve the agricultural activities and to enhance better farming practices by the beneficiaries on basic modern agriculture practices, trainings were organized and conducted for farmers in both Malakal town and the POC, targeting 1 per HH (a total of 354 HHs: female 263 and Male 90) trained on sustainable agro-practices and climate smart agriculture (5 days in total), as well as demonstration plots with monthly vouchers to protect their livelihoods. We over-reached by 560 individuals, because the number of individuals living in one HHs varies from one house to another (not 6 per HH as planned). Pests and diseases continue to remain a challenge to farmers and are hampering crops during the season, reported to be at 35%. The unpredictable season also affects farmers planting time since rains fall late or do not fall when farmers have planted anticipating rainfall at the time. This unforeseen challenge caused a lot of crop damage in a dry split period. Despite these challenges farmers faced, they still reported that 54.3% of the harvested crops were used for their own consumption at home and few other for treatment, school fees for their children and offer as gifts to desperate relatives who have had food for some time. Average income earned from sale of crops harvested has improved as compared to previous years, farmers reported an average income of 8,000 SSP compared to 2,000 SSP in 2019.
Men

title.narrative: % of budget spent on capacity building of national and local actors

comment.narrative: % of budget spent on capacity building of national and local actors

Achieved 1% of the total original budget for capacity building of AC and YC teachers local authorities, ministries, services providers, traditional/ religious leaders on adolescent development. MHM, as well as gender equality and prevention of GBV.

title.narrative: % of budget that went to national and local actors

comment.narrative: % of budget that went to national and local actors
Achieved 9% of a total original budget given to SAADO, however with the localization top up we have achieved 11% of a total budget given to SAADO.

title.narrative: Number of national or local actors supported with capacity building

comment.narrative: Number of national or local actors supported with capacity building

A total of 21 (11 male, 10 female) Project Management Committees members, capacity strengthening of the service providers, line ministries, government offices (police/security, court, health and agriculture), educational personnel in schools, traditional/religious leaders, influential community members, 4 community structures/committees, as well as SAADO (local partner) on thier roles.

title.narrative: Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus

description.narrative: Humanitarian support: capacity building in protection

comment.narrative: Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus
female

Capacity building activities were conducted for 80 (Female 22, Male 58) traditional/religious leaders and other influential community members on Gender equality and GBV, SRHR and MHM, including training for 80 (29 Female, 51 Male) staff from service providers and line ministries on adolescent development, MHM, as well as Gender equality, prevention of GBV and referral pathways. Capacity building for 12 (5 Male, Female 7) local partners (SAADO under SSJR6) also took place. It was a 4-day training which was facilitated by the Child Protection Specialist, starting from the 11th to 12th of March 2020. Capacity building of 150 teachers (Male - 131, Female - 19) and other educational personal (matrons and patrons) on adolescent development, MHM, as well as gender equality and prevention of GBV.

title.narrative: Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific GBV prevention measures

comment.narrative: Number of persons reached by the implementation of specific GBV prevention measures
women

50 Adolescent caregivers were given positive parenting sessions on coping with Covid-19. The first group of 25 adolescent girl mothers were trained on the 13th -14th May 2020 in Malakal town while the second group of 25 adolescent girl mothers were also trained on the 22nd - 23rd May 2020 in Malakal PoC respectively. 10 adolescent clubs were formed, 9 in schools and 1 out of school, and 2 youth clubs, to make a total of 12 clubs. SAADO trained 200 (Boys 100, Girls 100) adolescent club members comprised of 20 members in each group and also trained 2 youth clubs which comprised of 15 members per each group. The total number of 2 youth clubs were 30 (14 young men and 16 young female). In addition, 315 most vulnerable adolescent Girls from P5-P8 in Schoolsrecieved MHM kits and orientation on Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM) followed by distribution of dignity Kits. Sanitary Making Materials for out-of-school girl mothers were also distributed. The composition of these dignity kits were re-usable sanitary pads, washing soap, underwear and cloth and were distributed to the most vulnerable adolescent girls. This helped the adolescent girls to feel comfortable and maintain their dignity during epidemics and public gatherings. 100 piece of sanitary pad making materials were also provided to out of school adolescent girl mothers followed by orientation on Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM) on the usage of sanitary making materials. This has enabled most girls to teach others to do the same for themselves which is more sustainables and also created opportunities to adolescent girl mothers to work together with other adolescents girl mothers.
men

title.narrative: Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements

comment.narrative: Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements
female

We managed to reach 9420 individuals during the International Women`s Day and youth days celebrations in Malakal Town and the Protection of Civilians site. The number reached includes Males under 18 (2837), females under 18 (3665), males above 18 (660), females above 18 (2258) in both Malakal town and Malakal PoC on 9th and 12th of March 2020 and youth day on 20th August 2020. Outreach peer to peer awareness raising was conducted by 10 Adolescent Clubs and 2 Youth Clubs in 3 schools to another adolescent in Malakal town.150 (Male 95, Female 55) attended. Closure of schools because of COVID-19 affected some activities since most of our activities for adolescents were done in schools. And again, when COVID-19 restrictions were relaxed, primary 8 and Senior 4 were busy in schools, hence it was difficult to conduct more sessions and trainings. Nevertheless we managed to discuss some few topics with adolescents which include child marriage, abortion and teenage pregnancy, which are rampant in Malakal as a result of COVID-19 outbreak and closing of schools. Community mobilizers also continued engaging in GBV Protection in Emergencies awareness raising in Malakal town and PoC sites. The number reached 480 (186 Men and 251 Women, 17 boys and 26 girls) during awareness raising. This enabled the girls now to understand their rights during awarenes raising and talk freely without fear regarding the decisions that affect their daily lives.
male
